Sometimes we talk to ourselves in supportive ways that help us be our best selves, and sometimes we talk to ourselves in hurtful or unproductive ways that make it harder to be our best selves. Juno came from a family of famous swordsmiths, the legendary Umbra family. She wanted to learn the family craft of making majestic swords, so that she could carry on the family legacy. Their swords were used in epic battles against dragons and supervillains. However, sword making did not come easily to her. Juno had a lot of trouble creating strong swords. The ones she made were either too small, too weak, or not comfortable to use in battle. 
One day when Juno was working, our supervillain Hex noticed her inside the workshop and saw the weak sword she was working on. He said “Hey, aren’t you the youngest member of the Umbra family?” She looked up in surprise; she didn’t even know anyone had been watching her. Before Juno could answer, Hex continued: “So the rumors are true! You really are terrible at making swords; you’re even worse than I imagined! You’ll never live up to your family name.” Hex’s words hit Juno like an arrow to her heart. She looked straight down at the sword she was working on, scrubbing it furiously with a steel wool polishing cloth, hoping Hex wouldn’t see that her lip was trembling. She thought about her older sister Alvina and her older brothers Eris and Clem and the powerful, elegant swords–with impossibly thin blades and jewel-encrusted hilts–that they turned out day after day. She had never made anything like that, and a lump rose in her throat thinking about Hex’s words. “He’s right, she told herself. I’ll never be able to do that.”Hex grinned to himself watching Juno on the verge of tears. He didn’t know what she was thinking, but he felt sure negative self-talk was setting in. He laughed evily and flew away.

Fortunately, Zip had been tracking Hex, knowing he was up to no good. When saw Hex fly off, he knew trouble had to be brewing nearby. After searching carefully in every nook and cranny, Zip finally spotted a sniffling Juno.

“Hey there,” Zip said gently, “I just saw an acquaintance of mine named Hex fly out of here. I hate to say it, but he has a bad habit of getting kids to use negative self-talk. You didn’t notice him doing that here, did you?”

“Negative self-talk?” Juno replied. “What’s that?” 

“Ah,” said Zip, “Negative self-talk is a very sneaky trickster. It is all the things we tell ourselves that make us feel hopeless and sad. It can creep into our minds when we least expect it and ruin good moments and make bad moments harder. Is there any chance you’ve been talking to yourself negatively?”

Juno let out a sob of frustration as the dam inside her broke and all her thoughts came tumbling out. “I’ve been telling myself that everyone in my family but me can make beautiful swords, and I’m going to be an embarrassment to my whole family. I’ve been telling myself that I am awful at this and it’s only a matter of time before everyone else finds out! But that’s not negative self-talk” she went on, “that’s just the truth!”

Zip smiled sympathetically. “I know just how you feel, and I know you have a big challenge ahead of you to master your family craft. But what happens next depends on you and what you decide to do. What you tell yourself will affect how you think, how you feel, what you do–and even what those swords look like. So tell me this, what does it take to become a masterful swordmaker?”

“I dunno,” Juno said sullenly. “Years of practice and hard work. Good teachers. Careful stone-setting techniques. The finest tools. Steady fingers and a sharp eye. All things I don’t have!”

“That’s a great list!” said Zip. “And you may be right–perhaps you haven’t had the years of practice and hard work that it takes to develop those steady fingers and sharp eyes. But I’m proud of you for being right here in this workshop where that practice and hard work can begin. I know you have the motivation to build this skill, but I think you need some positive self-talk, too. So, instead of telling yourself, ‘I am awful at this and it’s only a matter of time before everyone else finds out,’ I want you to say, ‘I am awful at this and it’s only a matter of time before I get better. I have faith that if I practice, work hard, and watch what the experts do, I will become an expert myself.”
